22771.title: What guidance on gifts do you require?

nodes.text: Can I offer a gift?
Can I accept a gift?
When is it not appropriate to accept a gift?

Giving an unearned reward to influence someone’s behaviour or approving an irregular payment to facilitate business processes is a form of bribery.  It is illegal.  This includes being asked for a fee by a supplier to tender for a contract.  This is and could be interpreted by others as a bribe.
We do not offer, give or receive bribes or make improper payments, or participate in any kind of corrupt activity, either directly or through any third party.

Engaging in any form of bribery or corruption, even an allegation, can result in criminal proscecution and can seriously damage our reputation and our business relationships and is never acceptable.  We would rather miss out on business than take this risk.
Do not pay.  Take action immediately. Report the situation to your line manager and the legal department.
Record any details of the request (time, date, by whom and how it was asked for).

Gifts are a legitimate part of business life.  They build goodwill and are often exchanged. Accepting a low value gift such as flowers or stationery is unlikely to put you as the recipient into a situation where your integrity, impartiality or judgement might be challenged or the company's reputation might be damaged if you accept them.  Most companies have a gift policy limiting the acceptance of gifts to small tokens like flowers to avoid such situations from happening.  Unless you feel that this isn't the case it is fine to accept the gift.
Accepting a low value gift is unlikely to be misconstrued as inappropriate behaviour by others. If it is low value and others would see it as such it should be ok to accept it.

If this gift or an item of a similiar value could be given by you in return as a proper business expense then it is fine to accept them.  If you are in doubt that you would be permitted to do so then check with your manager first or decline the gift.
Report the gift to your line manager and be clear that you have accepted it and the reason for it.
Always acknowledge the gift in writing to the sender.
Gifts should only be accepted as a one off and not one of many from the same person / company.  The exception would be company branded promotional items.
If you have been offered or have received non promotional gifts such as flowers or similar from this person or company before, talk to your manager before accepting.

The danger of accepting multiple gifts from business contacts is that, unfairly or not, colleagues and others including other business partners, may question your impartiality and professional integrity.  The more frequently you accept gifts the more chance this may happen.

Although you may believe that the flowers are offered with no ulterior motive, multiple gifts even of low value, could be misinterpreted by others who could perceive acceptance as making you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated.  It maybe safer to decline on this occasion than to take the risk.

As the gift is not a promotional item do not be embarrassed to decline it and be clear that you are by doing so in writing.  Simply explain that you are not in a position to accept them using the rules and the reasons given here as explanation.
If you feel it is appropriate to accept the flowers, report them to your line manager.
Always acknowledge the acceptance of a gift in writing to the sender.
